messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>>>The other part, of course, is that 100% code coverage still doesn't
>>>mean you've tested everything... there will still be logic paths
>>>through the code that are not exercised, and in any large enough
>>>program (say, above 10000 lines), these paths rapidly approach
>>>infiinty.
>>>
>>>Bob Glass' "Facts and Fallacies" has a good write-up on this.
>>>
>> I have to completely disagree with this.
>>
>> First of all we are talking about unit tests, which suppose to work
>>with isolated components. I'll leave aside discussion that you can't
>>always isolate components from the infrastructure because it is a
>>separate topic and in fact quite achievable in my opinion.
>>
>> Now, for each isolated unit of code we have an unit test. When
>>application size grows complexity of unit tests would grow linearly and
>>not exponential and as a result close to 100% test coverage is not any
>>more difficult to achieve for large codebase then for a small codebase.
>
> I guess it depends what you mean by "code coverage".
>
> If you mean "that segment of code was run by at least one test", then yes,
> it's not "too hard" (albeit still sometimes too complex to be worth the
> trouble).
>
> If you mean "all possible paths of execution have been tested", then it's
> clearly impossible because it's exponential with the number of branches in
> your code (see "cyclomatic complexity").

"all possible paths" coverage referred at
http://www.bullseye.com/coverage.html#basic_path is obviously not only
difficult to cover and but also unpractical to verify.

I would say that "condition" or "branch" coverage variants would
give quite acceptable outcome in most of the cases. This is sort of
similar to the concept of unit testing where each condition
prectically interpreted as an individual unit.
See http://www.bullseye.com/coverage.html#basic_condition
If I am not mistaken this sort of coverage idea is used in an
opposide direction by Agitator tool that Kent Beck somehow involved to.

Not to mention, of course, that method with high degree of
complexity can be broken into individually testable units... :-)

regards,
Eugene
